metadata./Title: Coinfection of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 and polyomavirus in a patient with coronavirus disease 2019 detected by enrichment next-generation sequencing: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 was found first in Wuhan and declared a pandemic 
by the World Health Organization. Coinfection with other respiratory viruses may occur, complicating the diagnosis 
and treatment of coronavirus disease 2019 . Herein, we identified a Karolinska Institute polyomavirus Stockholm 60 
present in a nasopharyngeal swab of a patient with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection using 
next-generation sequencing with an enrichment method.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 24-year-old Indonesian woman was admitted to our institution due to a cough, cold, and sore 
throat. She had no family history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, and she was well. Her vital signs were as follows: heart rate, 84 beats per minute; respiratory rate, 22 breaths per minute; temperature, 39 °C; and pulse oximetry, 
96% on room air. She had runny nose and slightly inflamed pharynx. Her nasopharyngeal swab and real-time polymerase chain reaction were positive for the coronavirus disease 2019 nucleocapsid and open reading frame genes, 
with cycle threshold values of 32.33 and 33.74, respectively. Whole-genome sequencing of severe acute respiratory 
syndrome coronavirus 2 was performed using the Nextera DNA Flex for Enrichment using the Respiratory Virus Oligos 
Panel, Illumina MiSeq instruments, and Illumina MiSeq reagent v3 150 cycles (2 × 75 cycles). The full genomes were 
aligned to the reference genome (NC_045512.2) by the Burrow–Wheeler aligner algorithm. The whole-genome 
sequencing showed coinfection of Karolinska Institute polyomavirus Stockholm 60 (NC_009238.1) with an overall 
coverage of 3561x. The patient was given acetaminophen, vitamin C, vitamin D, and zinc for the treatment and discharged uneventfully from the hospital 4 days after admission. Then, 2 weeks after discharge, she visited the outpatient clinic without any further concerns.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This report presents a case of Karolinska Institute polyomavirus and severe acute respiratory syndrome 
coronavirus 2 coinfection in a patient with nonspecific clinical manifestation. Further studies with a larger sample size 
are mandatory to clarify the association between severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 and Karolinska

Background
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) was first 
found in Wuhan and declared a pandemic by World 
Health Organization later. COVID-19 has many signs 
and symptoms and classified as asymptomatic, mild 
(cough, fever, and headache), moderate, and severe 
(acute respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, and organ 
failure) [1 , 2].
Some recent studies have reported that the coinfec tion rates between severe acute respiratory syndrome 
coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and other viral and bac terial pathogens are higher than previously anticipated 
[3, 4]. SARS-CoV-2 coinfection with other respira tory pathogens may worsen patient outcomes [3 , 4]. 
In patients with severe disease, testing for seasonal 
respiratory viruses should be conducted to determine 
the most appropriate treatment [1 ]. However, another 
study reported no significant difference in positive 
SARS-CoV-2 positivity rates in patients with and with out coinfection. Routine testing for non-SARS-CoV-2 
respiratory pathogens during a pandemic is likely to 
yield clinical benefit if other pathogens present alter 
disease management or therapy [5 ]. In their study, Zhu 
et  al. reported that 94.2% of patients with COVID-19 
were co-infected with one or more other pathogens; 
however, no deaths occurred, and only three patients 
were admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) [4 ]. No 
significant difference in the coinfection proportions 
was found between ICU and non-ICU patients [6 ].
The prevalence of coinfection, including with viruses, 
bacteria, and fungi, in patients with COVID-19 varies 
[7]. Coinfection might lead to antibiotic resistance, host 
immune inhibition, and poor disease prognosis [8 , 9]. A 
study reported that SARS-CoV-2 coinfection with other 
respiratory pathogens in children increases inflamma tory responses [10]. In addition, simultaneous testing 
for SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory pathogens is 
recommended to determine the most appropriate treat ment and diagnosis for the patients [6 ]. These proposed 
the need for further studies about the prognosis of 
patients with coinfection.
Herein, we report the case of Karolinska Institute 
polyomavirus (KIPyV) Stockholm 60 detected in a 
nasopharyngeal swab of a patient with COVID-19 using 
next-generation sequencing (NGS) with an enrichment 
method.Case presentation
A 24-year-old Indonesian woman had come to our 
institution 3 days previously due to a cough, cold, and 
sore throat. She had no family history of hypertension 
and diabetes mellitus and was well. Her vital signs were 
as follows: heart rate, 84 beats per minute; respira tory rate, 22 breaths per minute; temperature, 39  °C; 
and pulse oximetry, 96% on room air. She had a runny 
nose and slightly inflamed pharynx. Given these signs 
and symptoms, the patient was further assessed for 
COVID-19, and a nasopharyngeal swab was taken on 
10 August 2020. The nasopharyngeal specimen was put 
into viral transport media. The sample was then sent 
for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and SARS-CoV-2 
whole-genome sequencing (WGS) [11]. Total viral RNA 
was extracted. A real-time PCR (RT-PCR) of SARSCoV-2 was performed using the Real-Q 2019-nCoV 
Detection Kit (BioSewoom, Seoul) and LightCycler® 
480 Instrument II (Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim), 
which was positive for nucleocapsid (N) and open read ing frame (ORF) genes, with a cycle threshold (Ct) of 
32.33 and 33.74, respectively.
Subsequently, WGS for SARS-CoV-2 was performed 
using NGS with an enrichment method. The doublestranded cDNA was synthesized from the total RNA 
using Maxima H Minus Double-Stranded cDNA Syn thesis (Thermo Fisher Scientific, MA, USA) and puri fied by a GeneJET PCR Purification Kit (Thermo Fisher 
Scientific). Then, library preparations were performed 
with the Nextera DNA Flex for Enrichment using the 
Respiratory Virus Oligos Panel, and genome sequenc ing was conducted using the Illumina MiSeq instru ment (Illumina, CA) with Illumina MiSeq reagent 
v3 150 cycles (2 × 75 cycles). The full genomes were 
aligned to the reference genome (NC_045512.2) by the 
Burrow–Wheeler aligner (BWA) algorithm [8 ]. Low 
coverages of WGS of SARS-CoV-2 were excluded. The 
result showed coinfection with KIPyV Stockholm 60.
The patient was given acetaminophen, vitamin C, 
vitamin D, and zinc as treatment and was discharged 
uneventfully from the hospital 4 days after admission. 
Then, 2 weeks after discharge, she visited the outpatient 
clinic without any further concerns.
This work has been reported in line with the CARE 
criteria [12].of enrichment-based next-generation sequencing in detecting viral coinfection in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2.

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Effect of KIPyV coinfection
KIPyV, first identified at Karolinska Institute, was dis covered accidentally during a systemic molecular screen ing to search for unknown viruses using respiratory 
tract samples. In their study, Ren et  al. detected KIPyV 
in 415 respiratory tract samples of children with symp toms of acute respiratory tract infections symptoms. For 
comparison with this study, 297 nasal and throat swabs 
were obtained from immunocompetent adults with lower 
acute respiratory tract infections. Both specimens were 
screened by PCR for the presence of polyomaviruses and 
other common respiratory pathogens. Consequently, 
none of the adult samples were positive, and KIPyV was 
found in 0.5% of pediatric samples [13]. Prezioso et  al. 
reported that, of 112 patients with COVID-19, 24.1% 
were co-infected with KIPyV. They also included oro pharyngeal swabs from 38 healthcare workers, which 
were negative for SARS-CoV-2 and KIPyV. In this study, 
a significant difference in the KIPyV infection rate was 
found between patients with and without SARS-CoV-2 
coinfection. This study also evaluated the SARS-CoV-2 
Ct values in the presence of KIPyV DNA. The Ct values 
were lower in the group with SARS-CoV-2 and KIPyV 
coinfection (median Ct: 25.63). These findings might con firm that these PyV do not suppress SARS-CoV-2 replica tion [14]. They proposed that KIPyV might act more as 
an opportunistic than a true respiratory pathogen [14]. 
Their results implied that SARS-CoV-2 might change the 
immune response of the host, resulting in higher replica tion rates of KIPyV [14]. Notably, patients with immuno compromised states might have a higher risk for infection 
or increased viral reactivation from latency [15].
In the present case, the symptoms of our case were sec ondary to COVID-19. COVID-19 coinfection has non specific clinical manifestations [1, 2], as in the present 
case. Notably, in patients with severe disease, testing for 
seasonal respiratory viruses is necessary to determine 
the most appropriate treatment [1]. In addition, no sig nificant difference in the coinfection proportions was 
found between the ICU and non-ICU groups [6]. Our 
patient was relatively stable and recovered uneventfully. 
Therefore, KIPyV coinfection might have not affected her 
clinical manifestation. However, differentiating between 
colonization and real infection on nasal swab WGS is 
very difficult.
NGS with enrichment
PCR has been the gold standard for diagnosing infec tious diseases. However, PCR may not detect sequences 
of microorganisms that are not similar to those targeted 
by the primers and probes. NGS can rapidly produce large volumes of sequencing data with lower sequenc ing costs. NGS can reconstruct pathogens’ complete 
genomes directly from nucleic acids. NGS may fail to 
reconstruct complete genomes of pathogens because of 
the low pathogen/nucleic acid ratio [16, 17]. We chose 
the enrichment method that allows large fragments of 
the targeted microorganism genomes to be reconstructed 
directly from complex biological samples containing a 
low pathogen/host nucleic acid ratio [16]. In addition, the 
enrichment method would resolve two important public 
health issues: detection of potential variant of interest 
or variant of concern of SARS-CoV-2 and other respira tory viruses in a single test [18]. Therefore, our finding 
proposed the advantage of the enrichment method over 
amplicon-based NGS to identify coinfection in patients 
with COVID-19.
Although the amplicon-based NGS is more commonly 
used for WGS of SARS-CoV-2, it has several limita tions; for example, the quality of sequences relies on the 
viral load in the nasopharyngeal swab and variants that 
might exist within the primer binding regions of the 
SARS-CoV-2 genome, and the possibility of dropouts of 
amplicon and bias of genome coverage among various 
amplicon regions [19].
Other challenges were encountered during the diag nostic process, including the decreasing number of 
positive subjects with Ct values ≤ 25 for WGS when the 
positivity rate of COVID-19 decreases, resulting in lower 
opportunity for early diagnosis of any potential new vari ant of SARS-CoV-2 [20].
Conclusions
This case report presents a case of KIPyV and SARSCoV-2 coinfection in a patient with nonspecific clinical 
manifestation. Further studies with a larger sample are 
mandatory to clarify the association between SARSCoV-2 and KIPyV coinfection, particularly on patient 
outcomes. Moreover, the findings propose the usefulness 
of enrichment-based NGS in detecting viral coinfection 
in patients with COVID-19.
